content: How can I help you today?
I've been having trouble sleeping lately. My mind just won't stop racing at night, and it’s been tough to deal with.
That sounds really challenging, having your mind race when you’re trying to sleep. What’s been on your mind lately?
It's mostly about work. I'm really worried that I might get fired soon. If that happens, I don't know how I'll manage to provide for my family, and that thought keeps me up every night.
It sounds like you’re carrying a lot of responsibility and fear about work and providing for your family. That worry must feel overwhelming at times. How have you been handling those feelings so far?

I’ve been trying to distract myself by scrolling on my phone, but I know it’s not helping. It just adds more random thoughts to my head, but honestly, I don’t know what else to do. Laying there with all the stress feels unbearable.

You’re doing your best to cope, turning to your phone to escape that overwhelming stress, even though it’s not offering much relief. It sounds like you’re looking for a way to quiet your mind and find some peace, especially when the stress feels too big to manage. What sort of things have helped you to feel calm or grounded in the past?

I can’t really think of anything specific. With everything going on, it feels like there’s no room to even figure out what might help. I usually just push through and hope I’ll eventually tire myself out enough to fall asleep.

It sounds like you’ve been carrying this by yourself, just trying to push through without a clear way to ease the stress. That exhaustion must be tough on you. Taking care of yourself when you're under so much pressure might feel like an uphill climb. Have you ever talked to someone, like a friend, family member, or professional, about what you’re going through?
Not really, this is the first time I’ve actually talked to someone about it. My partner pushed me to come, and I didn’t think anyone else could really help. It’s hard for me to open up like this.

Opening up takes courage, especially when you’ve been trying to manage everything on your own. It shows a lot of strength that you’re willing to share what’s been going on, even though it isn’t easy. What made you decide to go ahead and talk today?

I think deep down, I know I can’t keep going like this. I want to be a good partner and a good parent, but this stress is just taking over everything. I figured maybe giving this a shot couldn’t hurt, even if I don’t fully know what to expect.

You’ve recognized the toll this stress is taking on your life, and stepping out of your comfort zone to explore something new shows how deeply you care about your family and yourself. It sounds like you want to find a way to regain some balance and be there for those you love. What do you think might change if you found a way to feel more at ease or to sleep better?

I think if I could sleep better and feel less stressed, I’d be a much better parent and partner. I’d have more energy and patience to spend time with my kids, and I wouldn’t feel so on edge all the time. Maybe I’d feel more confident at work too, but I don’t know how to get to that point. It just feels so far away right now.

It sounds like you have a clear picture of how things could improve—not just for yourself, but for your family and even your work. That’s a lot to strive for, and it’s understandable that it feels distant right now. What do you think might be a small step that could help make those changes feel more within reach?

Maybe trying to limit my phone at night would help, but honestly, I don’t know if I have the willpower for that right now. When I’m lying there, it’s the only thing that keeps my brain from completely spiraling.

Trying to limit your phone feels like it could be helpful, but it also sounds like it’s been a tool you rely on to cope with the intensity of your thoughts. It’s okay to feel unsure about stepping away from something that’s giving you even a little relief in those moments. What would make it easier for you to experiment with a different way to calm your mind at night?

Maybe if I had something else to replace using my phone, it could help. Like maybe some kind of routine or distraction that feels calming but doesn’t make my brain race more. I’m just not sure what that would even look like.

You’re open to the idea of replacing the phone with something calming, something that helps without adding more to your thoughts. It shows you’re already thinking of ways to redirect your energy in a healthier direction. Is there any kind of activity—something simple or soothing—that you’ve heard about or been curious to try before?

Maybe something like reading or listening to calming music could help, but I’m not really sure if it’d work. I’ve also heard people talk about meditation, but I’ve never done it, and I don’t know if I could sit still long enough to do it. It’s hard to even know where to start.

You’re exploring possibilities, like reading, calming music, or even meditation, but you’re unsure of what might work for you or how to approach something new. That uncertainty makes sense, especially when it feels hard to settle your mind. Would you like to talk about how you might try one of these options, or is there another approach you’re curious about?
